title: Online Behavior: Not as Mean as You Think
summary: Many people think the internet is full of mean comments, but it's not as bad as they believe. For example, on Reddit, Americans guess that 43% of users post very toxic comments, but research shows it's only about 3%. This means people overestimate how common bad behavior is online. Researchers studied this by asking over 1,000 adults what they think about online toxicity and comparing it to real data. They found that people often think toxic posts are much more common than they actually are, like on Facebook where they guess 47% share false news, but it's really 8.5%. This mistake can make people feel sad about society. Even when people can spot mean posts, they still think many users make them. The study also showed that telling people the truth about how rare toxicity is can make them feel more hopeful and less worried about society. Most toxic content comes from a small group of very active users, not everyone, so remembering this can help people feel better about using the internet.

background_read: This article is about how people often think the internet is a mean place, but research shows it's not as bad as they believe. Scientists studied this by asking adults what they think and comparing it to real data from sites like Reddit and Facebook. They found that people overestimate how common toxic behavior is, which can make them feel pessimistic about society. Learning the truth can help people feel more hopeful. The study helps us understand that most users are not mean online, and a small group causes most of the problems.
Article_Structure: WHO: Researchers Angela Y. Lee, Eric Neumann, and their team studied American adults.
WHAT: They found that people think online toxicity is more common than it really is, like on Reddit and Facebook.
WHERE: The study focused on online platforms like Reddit and Facebook in the United States.
WHY: To show that mistaken beliefs about online behavior can make people feel sad about society, and correcting them can increase optimism.

perspectives.description: Scientists use surveys and data to prove that people overestimate online toxicity and that correcting this can improve social attitudes.
